text: in years past the city of Jacmel was
famous throughout Haiti for the
elaborate masks and costumes made by
local artists for Carnival the
nationwide party celebrating excess and
pleasure before the austere days of
Catholic blend Jacmel artists like onel
Basel a consider their masks more than
just party accessories they are
political statements nava jackman for me
carnival and Jacmel is a story because
it's a message we are passing along what
we are seeing what we are experiencing
this is the message that we are passing
along and we construct that message out
of garbage but this year carnevale has
been officially cancelled throughout
Haiti there is little to celebrate
artists like Basel a no longer have a
platform to display their work
thoughtful must getting to provide this
is a mask that I have prepared for
Carnival but since the disaster struck
we won't be able to present it before
the earthquake basel ii finished the
centerpiece of this year's collection an
effigy of haitian president Rene Preval
who has been widely criticized for a
lack of leadership after the disaster
Basel a expressed his opinion of the
president through his art so see if
we've uh this is Preval where he closes
one eye on the people that are starving
in the country the other eye is open on
the dollar bill the white man has a key
to the lock that his closing prove all's
mouth so he can't speak his mouth is
locked so he never says a word for the
people that are starving in the country
I don't recognize him as a person here
as far as I'm concerned he has abandoned
his post Basel a lost much more than
just a venue to showcase his masks in
the earthquake he lost his livelihood he
used to make most of his money selling
masks and art during carnival when
tourists would flood the town and locals
would buy his masks for their own
costumes i got mail as I couldn't get
with the pontifical actually I had to
borrow money from a loan shark to get
ready for carnival now I'm in big
trouble because I don't know how I'm
going to repay there is no money all my
stuff is broken
house is broken basel a says his other
forms of income have also dried up he
used to teach art and mass making to 40
kids in the neighborhood but their
parents can no longer afford to pay for
lessons like most of the rest of Jacmel
basel a also lost his home in the
earthquake he now lives with his wife
and son in a tent pitched in the street
outside his shop he can't afford food so
relies on meals from his wealthier
neighbors yeah my sciatic to risk even
my work usually sells to tourists all my
hopes are with them but since so few
tourists actually came to my country to
begin with after what's happened they'll
definitely not be coming now I see no
hope for me and my child
in the end basel a and the other mask
makers of Jacmel did get to show off
their work though not in the festive
atmosphere of carnivale instead local
artists organized a silent funeral
procession honoring the victims of the
earthquake an estimated 1,000 people
followed a brass band to the cemetery
basel a's proved all masks drew a lot of
attention
